questiontext.text: Suppose that 10 researchers each independently draw a random sample from the same population. The samples are smaller than the population and do not include the entire population. Suppose they calculate a point estimate on this basis. What can you say about the point estimates of the various researchers?

generalfeedback.text:
Â The larger the samples, the closer the point estimates are likely to be.

Levels of Difficulty
Easy

M&T Hypothesis testing: means
Default value

M&T Hypothesis testing: proportions
Default value

M&T Sampling
Default value

answer.text: The point estimates are always equal to each other
The smaller the samples, the closer the point estimates are likely to be.
The point estimates are equal to each other if the samples are the same size.
The larger the samples, the closer the point estimates are likely to be.
